FRED Tags

Sam Boysel

2022-09-12

Source: vignettes/fredr-tags.Rmd
fredr-tags.Rmd

Introduction 

library(fredr)

This vignette is intended to introduce the user to fredr functions for the Tags endpoint of the FRED API.

FRED series are assigned tags as an attribute for classification. Each FRED tag is identified by a string ID. For example:

  • “annual”, “monthly”
  • “census”, “bls”
  • “usa”, “county”
  • “manufacturing”, “exports”, “households”
  • “sa” (i.e. “seasonally adjusted”)

The following examples illustrate usage of the Tags endpoint functions in fredr.

Get series tags

The function fredr_tags() returns a list of tags matching the request. The data returned is a tibble in which each row represents a FRED tag. For example, running fredr_tags() without any parameters returns the top 1000 FRED tags ordered by number of series who are assigned the tag (but here we limit to just 10):

fredr_tags(limit = 10)
#> # A tibble: 10 × 6
#>    name                              group_id notes      created popul…¹ serie…²
#>    <chr>                             <chr>    <chr>      <chr>     <int>   <int>
#>  1 nsa                               seas     "Not Seas… 2012-0…      99  736222
#>  2 usa                               geo      "United S… 2012-0…     100  654724
#>  3 public domain: citation requested cc        NA        2018-1…      99  608802
#>  4 annual                            freq     ""         2012-0…      88  490602
#>  5 county                            geot     "County o… 2012-0…      76  330600
#>  6 nation                            geot     ""         2012-0…      99  261128
#>  7 census                            src      "Census"   2012-0…      79  237310
#>  8 monthly                           freq     ""         2012-0…      95  214506
#>  9 copyrighted: citation required    cc        NA        2018-1…      88  207104
#> 10 bls                               src      "Bureau o… 2012-0…      88  175684
#> # … with abbreviated variable names ¹​popularity, ²​series_count

To return specific tags by tag name, specify multiple tags in a single string by delimiting with a semicolon:

fredr_tags(tag_names = "gdp;oecd", limit = 10)
#> # A tibble: 2 × 6
#>   name  group_id notes                                   created popul…¹ serie…²
#>   <chr> <chr>    <chr>                                   <chr>     <int>   <int>
#> 1 gdp   gen      Gross Domestic Product                  2012-0…      80   74130
#> 2 oecd  src      Org. for Economic Co-operation and Dev… 2012-0…      75   64074
#> # … with abbreviated variable names ¹​popularity, ²​series_count

Return tags for a given group ID:

fredr_tags(
  tag_group_id = "geo",
  limit = 50L
)
#> # A tibble: 50 × 6
#>    name  group_id notes                    created               popul…¹ serie…²
#>    <chr> <chr>    <chr>                    <chr>                   <int>   <int>
#>  1 usa   geo      United States of America 2012-02-27 10:18:19-…     100  654724
#>  2 tx    geo      Texas                    2012-02-27 10:18:19-…      59   35992
#>  3 ga    geo      Georgia (U.S. state)     2012-02-27 10:18:19-…      50   20786
#>  4 ca    geo      California               2012-02-27 10:18:19-…      62   18218
#>  5 va    geo      Virginia                 2012-02-27 10:18:19-…      49   17548
#>  6 nc    geo      North Carolina           2012-02-27 10:18:19-…      51   17332
#>  7 oh    geo      Ohio                     2012-02-27 10:18:19-…      49   16538
#>  8 il    geo      Illinois                 2012-02-27 10:18:19-…      50   16356
#>  9 ky    geo      Kentucky                 2012-02-27 10:18:19-…      45   15540
#> 10 in    geo      Indiana                  2012-02-27 10:18:19-…      48   15420
#> # … with 40 more rows, and abbreviated variable names ¹​popularity,
#> #   ²​series_count

Search for tags by text:

fredr_tags(search_text = "unemployment")
#> # A tibble: 2 × 6
#>   name         group_id notes                            created popul…¹ serie…²
#>   <chr>        <chr>    <chr>                            <chr>     <int>   <int>
#> 1 unemployment gen      ""                               2012-0…      72   32392
#> 2 nairu        gen      "Non-Accelerating Inflation Rat… 2012-0…      18       2
#> # … with abbreviated variable names ¹​popularity, ²​series_count

Note that the example above searches for tags matching "unemployment". To search for the set of series with tags matching "unemployment", use fredr_series_search_tags():

fredr_series_search_tags(
  series_search_text = "unemployment",
  limit = 100L
)
#> # A tibble: 100 × 6
#>    name                              group_id notes      created popul…¹ serie…²
#>    <chr>                             <chr>    <chr>      <chr>     <int>   <int>
#>  1 nsa                               seas     "Not Seas… 2012-0…      99   46672
#>  2 usa                               geo      "United S… 2012-0…     100   42174
#>  3 public domain: citation requested cc        NA        2018-1…      99   41880
#>  4 bls                               src      "Bureau o… 2012-0…      88   37998
#>  5 unemployment                      gen      ""         2012-0…      72   32770
#>  6 county                            geot     "County o… 2012-0…      76   28428
#>  7 annual                            freq     ""         2012-0…      88   23752
#>  8 household survey                  gen      "Current … 2012-0…      62   20066
#>  9 monthly                           freq     ""         2012-0…      95   19086
#> 10 rate                              gen      ""         2012-0…      85   15088
#> # … with 90 more rows, and abbreviated variable names ¹​popularity,
#> #   ²​series_count

Get related series tags

The function fredr_related_tags() returns a list of tags related to the set of tags matching the request. The data returned is a tibble in which each row represents a tag related to the tags specified in tag_names. For example, to get the set of tags related to the tags "monetary aggregates" and "weekly":

fredr_related_tags(tag_names = "monetary aggregates;weekly")
#> # A tibble: 16 × 6
#>    name                              group_id notes      created popul…¹ serie…²
#>    <chr>                             <chr>    <chr>      <chr>     <int>   <int>
#>  1 nation                            geot     ""         2012-0…      99      20
#>  2 usa                               geo      "United S… 2012-0…     100      20
#>  3 discontinued                      gen      ""         2012-0…      65      18
#>  4 frb                               src      "Board of… 2012-0…      79      18
#>  5 h6                                rls      "H.6 Mone… 2012-0…      50      18
#>  6 public domain: citation requested cc        NA        2018-1…      99      18
#>  7 sa                                seas     "Seasonal… 2012-0…      88      14
#>  8 m3                                gen      "M3 Money… 2012-0…      41       8
#>  9 m2                                gen      "M2 Money… 2012-0…      45       6
#> 10 nsa                               seas     "Not Seas… 2012-0…      99       6
#> 11 m1                                gen      "M1 Money… 2012-0…      46       4
#> 12 copyrighted: citation required    cc        NA        2018-1…      88       2
#> 13 currency                          gen      ""         2012-0…      61       2
#> 14 frb stl                           src      "St. Loui… 2012-0…      67       2
#> 15 funds                             gen       NA        2020-0…      24       2
#> 16 mzm                               gen      "MZM Mone… 2012-0…      24       2
#> # … with abbreviated variable names ¹​popularity, ²​series_count

To filter these results to tags belonging to the “General” tag group:

fredr_related_tags(
  tag_names = "monetary aggregates;weekly",
  tag_group_id = "gen"
)
#> # A tibble: 6 × 6
#>   name         group_id notes             created                popul…¹ serie…²
#>   <chr>        <chr>    <chr>             <chr>                    <int>   <int>
#> 1 discontinued gen      ""                2012-02-27 10:18:19-06      65      14
#> 2 m3           gen      "M3 Money Stock"  2012-02-27 10:18:19-06      41       8
#> 3 m2           gen      "M2 Money Stock"  2012-02-27 10:18:19-06      45       4
#> 4 mzm          gen      "MZM Money Stock" 2012-02-27 10:18:19-06      24       4
#> 5 funds        gen       NA               2020-05-11 13:13:02-05      24       2
#> 6 m1           gen      "M1 Money Stock"  2012-02-27 10:18:19-06      46       2
#> # … with abbreviated variable names ¹​popularity, ²​series_count

To filter these results even further, keep only the tags matching the string "money stock":

fredr_related_tags(
  tag_names = "monetary aggregates;weekly",
  tag_group_id = "gen",
  search_text = "money stock"
)
#> # A tibble: 4 × 6
#>   name  group_id notes           created                popularity series_count
#>   <chr> <chr>    <chr>           <chr>                       <int>        <int>
#> 1 m3    gen      M3 Money Stock  2012-02-27 10:18:19-06         41            8
#> 2 m1    gen      M1 Money Stock  2012-02-27 10:18:19-06         46            4
#> 3 m2    gen      M2 Money Stock  2012-02-27 10:18:19-06         45            4
#> 4 mzm   gen      MZM Money Stock 2012-02-27 10:18:19-06         24            2

Get series by tag names

The function fredr_tags_series() returns a list of series assigned tags matching the request. As with the functions for the Series endpoint, the data returned is a tibble in which each row represents a series. For example, to get all series tagged with "gdp":

fredr_tags_series(tag_names = "gdp")
#> # A tibble: 1,000 × 16
#>    id        realt…¹ realt…² title obser…³ obser…⁴ frequ…⁵ frequ…⁶ units units…⁷
#>    <chr>     <chr>   <chr>   <chr> <chr>   <chr>   <chr>   <chr>   <chr> <chr>  
#>  1 A001RD3A… 2022-0… 2022-0… Gros… 1929-0… 2021-0… Annual  A       Inde… Index …
#>  2 A001RG3A… 2022-0… 2022-0… Gros… 1929-0… 2021-0… Annual  A       Inde… Index …
#>  3 A001RI1A… 2022-0… 2022-0… Gros… 1930-0… 2021-0… Annual  A       Perc… % Chg.…
#>  4 A001RI1Q… 2022-0… 2022-0… Gros… 1947-0… 2022-0… Quarte… Q       Perc… % Chg.…
#>  5 A001RL1A… 2022-0… 2022-0… Real… 1930-0… 2021-0… Annual  A       Perc… % Chg.…
#>  6 A001RL1Q… 2022-0… 2022-0… Real… 1947-0… 2022-0… Quarte… Q       Perc… % Chg.…
#>  7 A001RO1Q… 2022-0… 2022-0… Real… 1948-0… 2022-0… Quarte… Q       Perc… % Chg.…
#>  8 A001RP1A… 2022-0… 2022-0… Gros… 1930-0… 2021-0… Annual  A       Perc… % Chg.…
#>  9 A001RP1Q… 2022-0… 2022-0… Gros… 1947-0… 2022-0… Quarte… Q       Perc… % Chg.…
#> 10 A001RV1A… 2022-0… 2022-0… Gros… 1930-0… 2021-0… Annual  A       Perc… % Chg.…
#> # … with 990 more rows, 6 more variables: seasonal_adjustment <chr>,
#> #   seasonal_adjustment_short <chr>, last_updated <chr>, popularity <int>,
#> #   group_popularity <int>, notes <chr>, and abbreviated variable names
#> #   ¹​realtime_start, ²​realtime_end, ³​observation_start, ⁴​observation_end,
#> #   ⁵​frequency, ⁶​frequency_short, ⁷​units_short

To get the top 100 most popular non-quarterly series tagged with "gdp":

fredr_tags_series(
  tag_names = "gdp",
  exclude_tag_names = "quarterly",
  order_by = "popularity",
  limit = 100L
)
#> # A tibble: 100 × 16
#>    id        realt…¹ realt…² title obser…³ obser…⁴ frequ…⁵ frequ…⁶ units units…⁷
#>    <chr>     <chr>   <chr>   <chr> <chr>   <chr>   <chr>   <chr>   <chr> <chr>  
#>  1 RKMTACCF… 2022-0… 2022-0… Chai… 1997-0… 2021-0… Annual  A       Inde… Index …
#>  2 VAACCFDQ… 2022-0… 2022-0… Chai… 1997-0… 2021-0… Annual  A       Inde… Index …
#>  3 AZADMINW… 2022-0… 2022-0… Chai… 1997-0… 2021-0… Annual  A       Inde… Index …
#>  4 TNADMINW… 2022-0… 2022-0… Chai… 1997-0… 2021-0… Annual  A       Inde… Index …
#>  5 NVARTENT… 2022-0… 2022-0… Chai… 1997-0… 2021-0… Annual  A       Inde… Index …
#>  6 NYARTENT… 2022-0… 2022-0… Chai… 1997-0… 2021-0… Annual  A       Inde… Index …
#>  7 GLAKARTE… 2022-0… 2022-0… Chai… 1997-0… 2021-0… Annual  A       Inde… Index …
#>  8 IDCONSTQ… 2022-0… 2022-0… Chai… 1997-0… 2021-0… Annual  A       Inde… Index …
#>  9 ORCONSTQ… 2022-0… 2022-0… Chai… 1997-0… 2021-0… Annual  A       Inde… Index …
#> 10 LADURMAN… 2022-0… 2022-0… Chai… 1997-0… 2021-0… Annual  A       Inde… Index …
#> # … with 90 more rows, 6 more variables: seasonal_adjustment <chr>,
#> #   seasonal_adjustment_short <chr>, last_updated <chr>, popularity <int>,
#> #   group_popularity <int>, notes <chr>, and abbreviated variable names
#> #   ¹​realtime_start, ²​realtime_end, ³​observation_start, ⁴​observation_end,
#> #   ⁵​frequency, ⁶​frequency_short, ⁷​units_short
